awd_titl_txt: A Sustainable ATE Coordination Network for Enhancing Personalized Learning Using Virtual and Augmented Reality-based Technology Innovations in Technician Education
awd_abstract_narration:
This Coordination Network (CN) enhances the technician workforce pipeline required for US manufacturing competitiveness across a range of advanced automotive and aviation manufacturing industries, via the use of virtual reality (VR)-based and augmented reality (AR)-based technologies.  It creates new virtual teaching spaces to provide highly accessible and personalized learning environments. The project yields a collective end-to-end innovation ecosystem, which lowers barriers for two-year colleges to embrace virtual and augmented reality-based, technology innovations to enhance personalized learning. It establishes a network for the national ATE community and advances state-of-the-art applications of VR- and AR-based learning technologies for use in a two-year college setting.

Composed of a national network of members from industry, academia, government and other ATE centers, this CN provides access to state-of-the-art VR and AR modules, designed to meet the needs of industry and educational and workforce development programs for two-year college students and entry and mid-level technicians. Specifically the CN has the following objectives: i) nurture new collaborations, ii) strengthen partnerships, iii) create new knowledge, and iv) disseminate existing knowledge to enhance current two-year technician education programs. This coordination network, based at Clemson University, convenes best-in-class innovators from two-year and four-year colleges, research universities, Manufacturing Extension Partnerships, National Network of Manufacturing Institutes, Workforce Investment Boards, professional societies, government, and industry.

por.por_cntn:
The Center for Aviation and Automotive Technological Education Using Virtual E-Schools (CA2VES) Coordination Network (CN) was established in 2017 and includes a broad membership from industry, academia, government and other ATE centers. Additionally, the CN contains access to state-of-the-art virtual and augmented reality modules, experts in the field, and educational and workforce development programs for two and four-year college students. Directing this effort has enabled CA2VES to understand the effectiveness of leveraging a network of experts who have extensive and proven expertise in areas including two-year college issues, faculty development, technician education, engineering and science, education and learning science, computer science and virtual reality, industry, workforce and economic development and public outreach and education to enhance the technology-based personalized learning paradigm. Over the last five years, the CN has developed, populated, and hosted supplemental instructional materials that could be used within a two-year college classroom to prepare students to obtain industry-approved certifications in the automotive and aviation industry. Faculty development programs were conducted for incorporating technology-based systems and assessing student learning outcomes in synchronous and asynchronous community college classroom settings.

 

This CN has impacted the ATE community by (1) identifying challenges of incorporating personalized learning and virtual reality at the two-year technological education level; (2) determining how technology can facilitate personalized learning with two-year colleges; (3) developing resources and best practices for development, delivery, and assessment of personalized educational system using VR and AR technology; (4) increasing understanding of the learning paths to adapt and personalize curriculum as students are learning; (5) developing a greater understanding of how to use learning data that is captured by educational technology tools; (6) and gaining access to high-quality educational materials required to complete industry-recognized certifications which will enable the development of a globally competitive STEM workforce. This network remains a sustainable resource, through CA2VES, for state-of-the-art research while disseminating innovations in virtual and augmented reality-based technologies for the ATE community and advanced manufacturing programs across the nation.
